Dialogue Context: User: Who invented photography? Agent: Nic\u00e9phore Ni\u00e9pce, Henry Fox Talbot and Louis Daguerre are the inventors. User: When did color photography arrise? Agent: Do you want to know the time it was first attempted or the foundation method was proposed or the first photograph was made? User: Actually, what is the foundation method?
Response: It records the photograph down into three different channels - Red, green, and blue light.  They are then mixed together to imitate the way the human eye senses color.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: The foundation of virtually all practical color processes, Maxwell's idea was to take three separate black-and-white photographs through red, green and blue filters.[40][41] This provides the photographer with the three basic channels required to recreate a color image. Transparent prints of the images could be projected through similar color filters and superimposed on the projection screen, an additive method of color reproduction.

Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 2: North America , candy apples (known as toffee apples outside North America), caramel apples or taffy apples are common Halloween treats made by rolling whole apples in a sticky sugar syrup, sometimes followed by rolling them in nuts.

Dialogue Context: User: How did the Great Depression end in the United States?
Response: Franklin Roosevelt's New Deal is widely viewed as the legislation that led to the end of the Great Depression.
Evidence Page Title 1: Great Depression in the United States
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: Three years into the depression, President Herbert Hoover, widely blamed for not doing enough to combat the crisis, lost the election of 1932 to Franklin Delano Roosevelt by a historically wide margin. Roosevelt's economic recovery plan, the New Deal, instituted unprecedented programs for relief, recovery and reform, and brought about a major realignment of American politics.

Dialogue Context: User: How do Ethiopians make Areki? Agent: Areki is a home distilled spirit that is often filtered through charcoal to remove off tastes or flavored by smoking or infusion with garlic. User: What do Ethiopians eat for breakfast?
Response: Four common dishes that are eaten for breakfast in Ethiopia are fit-fit (or fir-fir), chechebsa (or kita firfir), fatira, and genfo.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: Fit-fit or fir-fir is a common breakfast dish.  It is made from shredded injera or kitcha stir-fried with spices or wat.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 2: Chechebsa (or kita firfir) resembles a pancake covered with berbere and niter kibbeh, or other spices, and may be eaten with a spoon.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 3: Another popular breakfast food is fatira. The delicacy consists of a large fried pancake made with flour, often with a layer of egg. It is eaten with honey.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 4: Genfo is a kind of porridge, which is another common breakfast dish. It is usually served in a large bowl with a dug-out made in the middle of the genfo and filled with spiced niter kibbeh.

Dialogue Context: User: How does the WHO decide what constitutes an epidemic and what constitutes a pandemic?
Response: A pandemic is a type of epidemic that has spread across a large region such as multiple countries or continents.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: A pandemic (from Greek πᾶν, pan, "all" and δῆμος, demos, "local people" the 'crowd') is an epidemic of an infectious disease that has spread across a large region, for instance multiple continents or worldwide, affecting a substantial number of individuals.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 2: An epidemic (from Greek ἐπί epi "upon or above" and δῆμος demos "people") is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of hosts in a given population within a short period of time. For example, in meningococcal infections, an attack rate in excess of 15 cases per 100,000 people for two consecutive weeks is considered an epidemic.[1][2]

User: What species are overfished in the Great Barrier Reef? Agent: Giant Triton and sharks are overfished. User: What do people dump in the water?
Response: The Great Barrier Reef has suffered from both the dumping of mining pollutants and dredge soil from construction of new ports.
Evidence Page Title 1: Environmental threats to the Great Barrier Reef
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: A freedom of information request by the Northern Queensland Conservation Council in 2014 showed that Queensland Nickel, owned by Australian politician Clive Palmer, discharged nitrate-laden water into the Great Barrier Reef in 2009 and 2011—releasing 516 tonnes (508 long tons; 569 short tons) of toxic waste water on the latter occasion. In June 2012, Queensland Nickel stated it intended to release waste water, continuously for three months, "at least 100 times the allowed maximum level as well as heavy metals and other contaminants".
Evidence Page Title 2: Environmental threats to the Great Barrier Reef
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 2: On 31 January 2014, the GBRMPA issued a dumping permit that will allow three million cubic metres of sea bed from Abbot Point, north of Bowen, to be transported and unloaded in the waters of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Dialogue Context: User: Where is the Parinacota located? Agent: Parinacota lies on the western margin of the Altiplano in the Central Andes. In Chile, where most of the edifice is located, Parinacota lies in the commune of Putre, Arica y Parinacota Region, and in Bolivia in the Oruro Department of the Sajama Province. User: How was Parinacota discovered?
Response: Parinacota was named by the Aymara people of the Bolivian Andes, and is a Native American language.  I cannot find a date for the first time it was named .
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: The name "Parinacota" is Aymara. Parina means flamingo[3] and quta lake.[4] Parinacota and its neighbour Pomerape are also known as the Nevados de Payachata,[1] "twins". This refers to the fact that the volcanoes resemble each other.[5]
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 2: Aymara (IPA: [aj.ˈma.ɾa] (audio speaker iconlisten); also Aymar aru) is an Aymaran language spoken by the Aymara people of the Bolivian Andes. It is one of only a handful of Native American languages with over one million speakers.[3][4]

Our Comment: If you go to the "Socio-economic effects" section in the "Great Depression" page, you will find out there are a few more countries. For example, Japan, Soviet Union, Spain and so on. Section outlines in Wikipedia pages can be useful in locating answers.
Dialogue Context: User: Did any specific country have a significantly less severe experience during the Great Depression?
Response: China was not affected as much due to being on the silver standard instead of the gold standard.
Evidence Paragraph First Sentence 1: China was largely unaffected by the Depression, mainly by having stuck to the Silver standard. However, the U.S. silver purchase act of 1934 created an intolerable demand on China's silver coins, and so, in the end, the silver standard was officially abandoned in 1935 in favor of the four Chinese national banks'[which?] "legal note" issues. China and the British colony of Hong Kong, which followed suit in this regard in September 1935, would be the last to abandon the silver standard.
